content.description: This is a fairly difficult traverse that travels across the overhang on the bottom of the pinnacle.  It is a good route to play around on, but there are better traverses in Flag.
content.protection: Not much.  Crashpad if you got one.

content.description:
Start on the center of the face on holds about chest height. Slide left halfway up and finish on jugs. Impure, but a brilliant 22 feet of fun.

Information from Chuffer's Flagstaff

Guide

.
content.protection: Couple Pads, couple spotters, some confidence.

content.description: On the aptly named Southwest Corner of the pinnacle there is a vertical arete with pretty nice holds.  Once you get past the overhang in the middle, it is pretty easy going.  Make sure to watch the topout as it gets kind of high.
content.protection: A crashpad and spotter are recommended, but not necessary as the landing is pretty sturdy.

content.description: A few feet right of the southwest corner, climb straight up good holds to the top. This also serves as the descent.

Just left of

Dungeon Master

, head up the arete. This is not the best but is a fun, steep problem with a tad spicy of a fall.

On the right side of the boulder there is a steep face.  You can start this problem with the two chalked holds there, but I recommend a sit start for a greater challenge.  Continue up these holds until you get to the pebble near the top, then top out.
content.protection: Crashpad recommended but not required.  Pretty sturdy landing.

content.description:
Stand start on the left side of the west (main) face. Climb straight up using a bulge and cracks joining the

Standard Route

to finish high left.

This is a SDS to the

Northwest Finger Crack

. It is fingery and a bit crunched at the base of the northwest corner of the boulder. Climb straight up using a bulge and finger cracks to join the

Standard Route

finishing high left.
Climb the center of the west face to the top. The idea is to swing/dyno to the top with your RH on the broken pebble. This problem has hurt some people and scared the crap out of others.
content.protection:
Bring lots of pads.

...taken from

flagstaffmountainbouldering…

thank him for his work.

content.description: On the back side of the boulder, there’s a steep cave. Starting with your hands on the rail and a heel out left going straight up is my line. EZ Harrison did a right variation which started off of low right foot an inch off the ground. The far left arete I did at V6 called Reluctant Dragon. I did both back in the Spring of 2010.
content.location: This is on the back side of the boulder.

content.description:
SDS start on the climber's left of the boulder, traverse right, and top out after rounding the corner on V0 south face. This is super fun and infrequently climbed while the hoards clusters at 1st overhang, but it's almost as good.

8a.nu grades

There's also at least three different ways to start this climb and move to the "heel jug". It is worth a session to play around on the variations.
